intro: Symphysia guadalupensis, commonly known as the Guadalupine, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes buckwheat and sorrel species. The plant is characterized by its upright growth habit and clusters of small, greenish-white flowers that bloom in late spring. Its leaves are typically lance-shaped and have a smooth or slightly hairy surface. Symphysia guadalupensis is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, making it a resilient species in harsh conditions.
